channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Japan’s Core Inflation Picks Up in May, Complicating BOJ’s Policy Steering
item.description: Persistent price growth is complicating the central bank’s policy stance, as tariff-related uncertainty makes it harder to determine the right timing for raising rates to curb inflation.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Canada imposes import curbs on steel to address fallout from Trump tariffs
item.description: Prime Minister Carney said the policy changes address ‘destabilization’ of metals sector due to U.S. trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Turkish Central Bank Stands Pat on Rates Despite Easing Inflation
item.description: The bank left its one-week repo rate at 46% as a means to counter volatile swings in the lira that followed the dramatic arrest and imprisonment of a prominent opposition politician, Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The Bank of England left its key rate unchanged, mirroring the Fed, as policymakers face a rise in oil prices that could push up inflation
item.description: Central banks are facing a new challenge as tensions between Israel and Iran threaten to push energy prices and inflation higher.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Foreign Investment Faces Third Year of Decline on Tariff Uncertainty, UN Warns
item.description: Overseas investment by businesses around the world is at risk of falling for a third straight year as rising tariffs and geopolitical tensions freeze big decisions about where to locate factories, the UN warned.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Philippines Central Bank Cuts Rates to Boost Economy, Warns of Geopolitical Risk
item.description: The rate cut was in line with market expectations, as benign domestic inflation and headwinds from tariffs and global geopolitics backed the case for continued easing.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: Taiwan Central Bank Stays on Hold Again as Uncertainty Persists
item.description: Taiwan’s central bank stood pat again, citing uncertainty around U.S. trade policy even as the export-reliant economy has stayed resilient so far in the face of tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: Swiss Central Bank Cuts Interest Rate to Deter Search for Safe Haven
item.description: Switzerland cut rates to zero to rein in the rapidly appreciating franc, which has acted as a safe haven for investors given raised concerns over U.S. trade policy and Middle East tensions.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Norges Bank Surprises With Rate Cut and Hints at Further Easing This Year
item.description: Inflation has declined since its March meeting and the outlook for the coming year indicates lower inflation than it had previously expected, the central bank said.
item.dc:creator: Dominic Chopping

item.title: European, Asian Stocks Fall Amid Geopolitical Tensions; U.S. Markets Closed
item.description: Investors continued to steer clear of risky assets amid geopolitical concerns centered on the Middle East while the U.S. markets were closed for the Juneteenth holiday.

item.title: Irish Central Bank Warns U.S. Policy Changes Could Lead to Slower Growth, Higher Debt
item.description: The rise in U.S. tariffs announced in early April would have a significant impact on economic growth over coming years, the central bank said in its quarterly outlook.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The Fed is trying to see how the dust will settle from the aftereffects of President Trump’s April 2 “Liberation Day” tariff announcements, among other policy changes
item.description: Fed Chair Jerome Powell is engaged in a balancing act: projecting confidence while admitting “we don’t know” what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: President Trump left the Group of Seven summit in Canada a day early without new trade deals, after signing onto a joint statement that calls for peace and stability in the Middle East
item.description: The president didn’t reach new trade deals but signed onto a joint statement calling for “peace and stability.”
item.dc:creator: Brian Schwartz

item.title: It’s a bad time to be a job seeker—especially if you are young
item.description: Slow hiring is especially daunting for those just starting out. “Right now, I’m pretending employment doesn’t exist,” says a recent college graduate.
item.dc:creator: Te-Ping Chen

item.title: BOE Set to Hold Rates Again Despite Cooling Jobs Market
item.description: The Bank of England is set to leave its key rate on hold Thursday as it charts a middle path between European central banks that have lowered borrowing costs more aggressively, and a Federal Reserve that has stopped cutting.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Consumers are making spending decisions in the fog of trade war, uncertain about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation of companies’ push for more profits
item.description: Consumers are making spending decisions in a haze of uncertainty about whether higher prices are the result of tariffs, inflation or companies’ push for more profits.
item.dc:creator: Joe Pinsker

item.title: The inventory of homes for sale is finally rising. Buyers aren’t interested
item.description: Home prices are up more than 50% in the last five years, and mortgage rates are holding above 6.5%. New listings haven’t been enough to jolt the market out of its slumber.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: President Trump wants China to open up to American goods. But China is moving toward a fortresslike economy that exports but doesn’t import.
item.description: President Trump is trying to further open up China’s market to U.S. companies as Beijing’s appetite for the rest of the world’s exports is diminishing.
item.dc:creator: Clarence Leong

item.title: Europe’s Exporters Feel the Chill From Trump Tariffs
item.description: Exports to the U.S. dropped by a third in April as squeezed demand from Trump’s tariffs led to a fall in factory output that suggests economic growth has slowed after a strong start to the year.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.K. Economy Shrinks on Tariff Hit
item.description: Production at the country’s factories contracted more than expected in April as evolving U.S. trade policy brought a halt to a surprising surge in activity.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: U.S.-China talks on trade resemble arms-control negotiations, with export controls being the key weapons in each side’s arsenal
item.description: The U.S.-China talks on trade resemble arms-control negotiations, with export controls being the key weapons in each side’s arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: Is the immigration crackdown already showing up in the labor market?
item.description: There are hints that the number of migrants in the U.S. labor force is already declining. It will take time, though, for the full effects to show up.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Timms

item.title: The World Bank says economic growth in the U.S. might halve this year as a result of President Trump’s tariff policies
item.description: The world’s largest economy is expected to grow by just 1.4% in 2025, a sharp deceleration from the 2.8% expansion recorded in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. job growth slowed slightly last month, a sign employers grew more cautious about hiring
item.description: The U.S. added 139,000 jobs in May, and the unemployment rate held steady at 4.2%.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: ECB Has Won Battle Against Inflation in the Eurozone, Villeroy Says
item.description: Europe has succeeded in bringing inflation under control after a surge driven by the end of the Covid-19 pandemic and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, the head of France’s central bank said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Early hints of a slowing labor market are raising the stakes for Friday’s release of the May jobs report, anticipated to show cooler hiring but a steady unemployment rate
item.description: Analysts polled by The Wall Street Journal are expecting the Labor Department’s report to show that the U.S. added a net 125,000 jobs in May.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Labor-Market Outlook Cautious Ahead of May Jobs Report
item.description: Early hints of a slowing labor market are raising the stakes for Friday’s release of the May jobs report, anticipated to show cooler hiring but a steady unemployment rate.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: President Trump’s tariffs threaten to crimp U.S. economic growth this year while boosting inflation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a new forecast
item.description: The research group expects the Fed to remain on hold this year, as the economy is hamstrung by uncertainty over whipsawing U.S. trade policy, according to the OECD.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Kirby

item.title: The Trump administration wants to sell shares in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. How it does so will have a big impact on home buyers and homeowners.
item.description: The Trump administration wants to sell shares in two government-controlled companies that are crucial for getting a mortgage. But it first needs to figure out what it wants the mortgage market to look like.
item.dc:creator: Veronica Dagher

item.title: Pending Home Sales Slump as Mortgage Prices Weigh
item.description: The number of homes going under contract in the U.S. fell sharply in April, as high mortgage prices continue to hamper the market, according to a monthly index.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: First-Time Home Buyers Downsize Amid Tight Supply, High Interest Rates
item.description: Home buyers are more willing to sacrifice size if it means finding a listing that works within their budget.
item.dc:creator: Denny Jacob

item.title: Sales of existing homes declined in April, after mounting economic uncertainty and steep housing costs pushed buyers away for the second consecutive month
item.description: The slowest sales pace for any April in 16 years indicates the spring selling season is shaping up as a bust.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: The University of Michigan said Friday its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May was 50.8, down about 3% from a final reading of 52.2 in April
item.description: The University of Michigan’s closely watched consumer-sentiment index was 50.8 in preliminary numbers for May.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: Heard on the Street: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all
item.description: Fear of rising prices can make upfront purchases rational for some groups, but not all.
item.dc:creator: Telis Demos

item.title: Americans are feeling gloomy about the economy after President Trump’s market-rattling first few months in office. But overall they are keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.description: People are still buying things at a steady clip, keeping the economy humming—for now.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Louise Ensign

item.title: American households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment
item.description: Households ended April feeling much worse about the economy than they did in March, according to a closely watched measure of consumer sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry
